articles.headline: Donald Trump Deflects Withering Fire on Muslim Plan
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump pointed to President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s actions toward Japanese, German and Italian immigrants during World War II as precedent.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump pointed to President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s actions toward Japanese, German and Italian immigrants during World War II as precedent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Repudiated across much of the political spectrum but defended on conservative talk radio, Donald J. Trump on Tuesday stood by his call to block all Muslims from entering the United States. He cast it as a temporary move in response to terrorism and invoked President Franklin D. Roosevelt’s authorization of the detention of Japanese, German and Italian immigrants during World War II as precedent.

articles.headline: For Immigrants, America Is Still More Welcoming Than Europe
articles.snippet: While its policies are often hostile, the United States is more successful than Europe at integrating immigrants into the national fabric.
articles.abstract: While its policies are often hostile, the United States is more successful than Europe at integrating immigrants into the national fabric.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States has some of the most hostile policies toward an immigrant population found in the developed world.

articles.headline: Bill Gates Takes On Climate Change With Nudges and a Powerful Rolodex
articles.snippet: Mr. Gates, acting as an envoy between the worlds of business and policy, has pressed global leaders and tech billionaires to team up on clean technology.
articles.abstract: Mr. Gates, acting as an envoy between the worlds of business and policy, has pressed global leaders and tech billionaires to team up on clean technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: LE BOURGET, France — When Bill Gates arrived at the Élysée Palace to meet the French president François Hollande and other officials in June, he brought a message.
articles.byline: By Coral Davenport and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Yahoo Is Said to End Plan to Spin Off Alibaba Stake
articles.snippet: The company will consider other options, including a possible sale of its core Internet operations, a person briefed on the matter said.
articles.abstract: The company will consider other options, including a possible sale of its core Internet operations, a person briefed on the matter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo will abandon plans to spin off its $31 billion stake in Alibaba, a Chinese e-commerce company, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Trump’s Plan to Bar Muslims Is Widely Condemned Abroad
articles.snippet: The Republican presidential candidate’s comments drew condemnation from Europe and beyond, as well as questions about the direction of the United States.
articles.abstract: The Republican presidential candidate’s comments drew condemnation from Europe and beyond, as well as questions about the direction of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A day after Donald J. Trump called for a ban on the entry of Muslims into the United States, much of the rest of the world on Tuesday looked at the American presidential election with a mix of befuddlement and despair.

articles.headline: Americans Attracted to ISIS Find an ‘Echo Chamber’ on Social Media
articles.snippet: As the White House takes on the challenge of the Islamic State, it is focusing on the online community of sympathizers in the United States, who number in the hundreds and fit no single profile.
articles.abstract: As the White House takes on the challenge of the Islamic State, it is focusing on the online community of sympathizers in the United States, who number in the hundreds and fit no single profile.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a lonely Virginia teenager named Ali Amin got curious about the Islamic State last year and went online to learn more, he found a virtual community awaiting. It had its own peculiar language, stirring imagery and just the warm camaraderie, sense of adventure and devotion to a cause that were missing from his dull suburban life.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Matt Apuzzo and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Dow Chemical and DuPont Are Said to Be in Merger Talks
articles.snippet: Two of the biggest and oldest chemical companies in the United States, each with a market value of roughly $60 billion, could become the world’s second-largest chemical maker in terms of revenue.
articles.abstract: Two of the biggest and oldest chemical companies in the United States, each with a market value of roughly $60 billion, could become the world’s second-largest chemical maker in terms of revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dow Chemical and DuPont, two of the biggest and oldest companies in the American chemical industry, are in talks to merge in what would be one of the largest transactions in a year full of huge deals, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Marco Rubio Quietly Undermines Affordable Care Act
articles.snippet: A provision slipped into a 2014 spending law by the Florida senator has tangled up the Obama administration and sent tremors through health insurance markets.
articles.abstract: A provision slipped into a 2014 spending law by the Florida senator has tangled up the Obama administration and sent tremors through health insurance markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A little-noticed health care provision slipped into a giant spending law last year has tangled up the Obama administration, sent tremors through health insurance markets and rattled confidence in the durability of President Obama’s signature health law.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Justices’ Comments Don’t Bode Well for Affirmative Action
articles.snippet: A majority of the justices seemed unpersuaded on Wednesday that an affirmative action plan at the University of Texas was constitutional.
articles.abstract: A majority of the justices seemed unpersuaded on Wednesday that an affirmative action plan at the University of Texas was constitutional.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An affirmative action plan at the University of Texas seemed to be in trouble at the Supreme Court on Wednesday. By the end of an unusually long and tense argument, a majority of the justices appeared unpersuaded that the plan was constitutional.

articles.headline: They Helped Erase Ebola in Liberia. Now Liberia Is Erasing Them.
articles.snippet: Thirty young men spent months burning the bodies of the infected. A year later, many relatives and fellow countrymen still can’t forgive them.
articles.abstract: Thirty young men spent months burning the bodies of the infected. A year later, many relatives and fellow countrymen still can’t forgive them.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSHALL, Liberia — It was around 3 in the afternoon when Sherdrick Koffa spotted, in neatly written script, the name on the body bag that he was preparing to set ablaze.

articles.headline: Yahoo to Keep Alibaba Stake but Spin Off Core Businesses
articles.snippet: Yahoo has decided to retain its Alibaba stake and will instead look at transferring its other assets, including Yahoo Japan, into a new company.
articles.abstract: Yahoo has decided to retain its Alibaba stake and will instead look at transferring its other assets, including Yahoo Japan, into a new company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Even after the Internal Revenue Service refused in September to grant its blessing to Yahoo’s proposed tax-free spinoff of its $32 billion stake in the Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba, Marissa Mayer was determined to go forward with the deal. In late October, Ms. Mayer, Yahoo’s chief executive, told shareholders that the plan was on track, and the preparations were still continuing last month.

articles.headline: After Making Enemies, Ted Cruz Tries to Make Friends
articles.snippet: Mr. Cruz has vaulted into the top tier of the Republican race as the consummate Washington bomb thrower, but now he is taking an almost academic approach to achieving likability.
articles.abstract: Mr. Cruz has vaulted into the top tier of the Republican race as the consummate Washington bomb thrower, but now he is taking an almost academic approach to achieving likability.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARLAN, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz had been at it for several minutes, offering handshakes and uneasy smiles, when he encountered an apparent holdout in the crowd.
